CUS reverses P/F decision, only three exceptions
By RICHARD WARING
The Committee on
Undergraduate Studies Tuesday
reversed its action of last week
on freshman grading policy and
ruled that with three exceptions
first semester grades for freshmen
will no longer be released outside
the Arts and Sciences division.
The exceptions are: students
applying to Hopkins 2-5 medical
program; student applying for
transfer to another institution
after freshman year, or students
who in their first year, received
sophomore standing. Only these
students may have their first
semester grades released.
The CUS vote on the motion
to alter last week's ruling was 7-2
and the Academic Council
ratified the action by a
unanimous vote at its Wednesday
session.

Mandel considering new aid

Money is big factor
for MSE Symposium

the next six weeks. Woodworth
noted that the entire budget
must be printed by January 1 for
the Governor's annual State of
the State address to the
Assembly.
One source in Annapolis,
however, doubted that the
Governor's first and major
budget proposal would include
the new plan for greater state
funding of private colleges and
universities. "It will probably
become part of a supplemental
budget later on in the session."
"To be frank," the source
continued, "the new plan won't
even be adoped if it means a tax
increase. Remember, this is an
election year."
The MCHE proposal emanates
from a five month study by a
special committee to develop a
permanent program of state
assistance to private higher
education.
Known as the "Pear
Committee," for its Chairman

Philip Pear who is a MCHE
member, the group presented
Mandel with an extensive 200
page report which included a
federally funded financial survey
of each of the 16 private
institutions by the New York
financial analysis firm Touche,
Ross and Company.
The Touche, Ross surveys
indicated that only five of the
sixteen institutions studied
would be operating without a
deficit in the fiscal year 1977.
Hopkins was not among the five.
The Pear Committee's report
to the Governor made three basic
recommendations:
1) That the current
distribution formula (of $500 per
degree conferred each year) be
changed to $243 per student
enrolled each year; the state
currently supports public colleges
and universities by such a
method, and the $243 figure is

for only one year and went to

and that the students should have

Five undergraduates, freshmen
Charles Henderson, Michael
Therrien, juniors Mike Kasper,
Sally Bergwerk and Junior Keith
Jorgensen were selected for the
Health Committee.
Lewin said he was especially
pleased with those who were
selected for the Health panel. He
noted that Therrien was in charge
of a camp infirmary last summer,
and that Jorgensen had
previously worked in the Brown
Infirmary.

The basic function of the
Health committee is to look into
complaints from students about
the Health Center.
Three sophomores and one
freshman were accepted for the
Issues Committee. Fred
Cortright, Rich Friedman, April
Morino and freshman Leah
Seidenfeld were selected.
The newly-established Issues
Committee is to act as a source
of information for students on
activities at other college
campuses. It is also to concern
itself with important natural
political events of possible
interest to students.

dominated by freshman

November 15, 1973 is the
application deadline for The
Winston Churchill Foundation

must be a U.S. citizen enrolled in
an institution participating in the
Churchill Scholarship program
and hold a B.A. degree. For more
detailed information and
applications, see Professor
Gordon Feldman, Department of
Physics, Campus Representative.

and box number on a piece of

and send it to: Chuck Slonim,
Box 897.

Volunteers are needed to
supervise a non-structured church
based drop-in program for
adolescents convenient to the
Hopkins campus. For more
information contact Jim Case at
the Office of the Chaplain or call
x1270 or x403.

SOC SCI
Letters and Papers, the new
social science journal, will be
distributed on November 13. All
undergraduates interested in
submitting papers for the next
issue should contact Steven
Schwartz, Box 1310, as soon as
possible.

SUSKIND
Dean Suskind will have his
office hours on Tuesday and
Friday from 1:30-5:00.

LIBES OPEN
The Eisenhower Library will
be open as usual on the 4-day
Thanksgiving holiday, only the
Circulation Desk will offer
service as usual, 8 a.m. until
midnight. Grad Reserves.
Audio-Visual, and Hutzler
Undergrad Reading Room will be
closed, but will re-open Sunday,
Nov. 25 at regular time.

Hopkins Union Desk. For more
information call the campus

november 9, 1973/news-letter/page 3

Hopkins Metro Center back at full operating capacity
By ALAN HIRSCH
The Hopkins Center for
Metropolitan Planning and
Research is "now working at its
normal operational level,"
according to the Center's
director, Dr. Jack Fisher.
The center has substantially
increased its staff size over the
past year, and no significant
increases in the Center's staff size
over the next few years are
foreseen by Fisher. The Center
this year employs 26 stipended
research assistants for its
projects, as compared to just two
last year.
The Metro Center, a
non-academic department of the
University which has as its
precursor the Center for Urban
Affairs, began operations last
year.

With the extensive aid of the
research assistants and three
research consultants, 19 members
of University academic
departments, and Metro Center
staffers, examine various aspects
of Urban problems through
research.
Researchers affiliated with the
Center are currently involved in
20 research programs in four
basic areas, Metropolitan
Growth, Government Service,
Social Relations in the City, and
the Environment. Research
projects involving international
exchange of men and ideas is also
a part of the Center's research
capacity.
The Center recently arranged
the visit to the U.S. of a group of
European Urban and
Environmental specialists who

SC group to meet
with Trustees Mon.
By MARK DALZELL
A six member delegation of •
the Student Council will meet
with several members of the
University's Board of Trustees
next Monday.
The upcoming meeting with
the Trustees was the primary
item for discussion on the
Student Council's Tuesday
evening agenda. The Council
also acted to approve the
selection of Amy Levin, a Junior,
as the Chairman for 3400 on
Stage and to accept the students
nominated to the Student UnIon
Governing Board, the Health
Committee, and the Issues
Committee.
Held at the request of the
Trustees and announced several
weeks ago, the meeting will cover
a broad range of topics with
emphasis on the conditions and
trends in undergraduate
education at the University.
The original members of the
Student Council chosen to meet
the Trustees were Shep
Senior Class
Hoffman
President, Dan Raab, Junior Class
President, Eric Rosenson,
Sophomore Class representative,
and Benetta Mansfield, Senior
Class representative. Since
Tuesday's SC meeting, Mark
Spatola, Freshman Class
President, and Andy Savitz,
President of the Student Council,
have been added.
President Muller and Robert
D.H. Harvey, Chairman of the
Board of Trustees, will attend the
Monday meeting. Tentatively
scheduled to appear are the
following trustees: Harrison L.
Winter, Vice-Chairman of the
Board, Morton K. Blaustein,
Alonzo G. Decker, Jr., and
Russell S. Passarella.
Yesterday, members of the
Student Council delegation met
to brief Muller on the form of
presentation to be used and the
questions to be raised by the
Council. The meeting with Muller
lasted approximately 45 minutes
and ended with Savitz being
asked, by Muller, to attend the
meeting with the Trustees.
At its Tuesday meeting the
Student Council was in
agreement with the general range
of topics to be discussed, but was

divided over the approach to be
taken with the Trustees.
Leon Barish , Junior
representative, saw the meeting
as an opportunity to expound
student philosophies on
education, while others, among
them John Colmers,
Vice-President of the SC, and
Hoffmann, stressed the need to
be more concrete and specific.
It was finally decided to
conduct the meeting as an
orientation of the Trustees in
academic conditions as viewed by
the Student Council.

By MARC DUVOISIN

mixed reactions the new pass-fail

Council Wednesday.
Under the new policy, first

Dr. Wickwire returns from Moscow with new insights
By LOUISA DAVIS
Dr. Chester Wickwire,
University Chaplain, returned
Saturday from a ten day trip to
Moscow as a participant in
the World Congress for Peace,
with a new understanding of
political oppression.
Wickwire served as an observer
for the United Church of Christ
and the Citizens' Committee for
a SANE World for the week-long
international forum for
world—wide peace movements.
He. was one of 178 U.S.
delegates along with Dr. Oakley

Saunders, a pediatrician at the
Hopkins Hospital, at the Russian
hosted event.
Wickwire worked with a
commission on Social Problems
and Human Rights in Moscow
and actually spoke to the
Congress on this subject. His
speech expressed his "concern

Commendation
The action by the Committee on Undergraduate Studies to
reverse its earlier decision to break promised confidentiality on
first semester freshman grades is commendable, as is the
unanimous vote by the Academic Council to support the CUS
reversal. Dean Suskind is apparently willing to abide by the twin
votes, and we commend him too.
But if students can take any comfort in the fact that their
voices were heard and respected, we should take little comfort
in the fact that the policy making process precludes significant
student participation except in the form of belated reaction. We
don't believe the University would be content with educating a
bunch of reactionaries, nor do we believe students have enough
of a role in deliberating over academic policies which directly
affect their academic careers.
The events of the past two weeks (insofar as the frosh grade
confidentiality incident is concerned) point to a severely closed
academic policy-making process. If students are content with
the process as it stands, so be it.. But we suggest that students
mobilize an effort to place a representative on the Academic
Council to prevent such an incident from ever occuring again.

To the Editor:
As you know there has been
much discussion and confusion
concerning the status of first
semester grades for the classes of
'75, '76, and '77. We would like to
take this opportunity to inform
you of the status of these grades.
On Tuesday, November 6th, the
Committee on Undergraduate
Studies (CUS) voted that no first
semester freshman grades will be
released except in the following
situations:
1) Students applying for transfer
during or at the end of the
freshman year.
2) Students applying to the
Johns Hopkins University AB-MD
(2-5 Medical program.
These first semester freshman
grades will only be released at the
written request of the institution
to which the student is applying
and then only upon written
consent of the student. The grades
from the first semester shall remain
on file for the internal use of the
division of Arts and Sciences.
There will be no other exceptions
to this rule. On Wednesday,
November 7th this motion was
passed unanimously by the
Academic Council and is now in
effect.
While we recognize that some
students may be adversely affected
by this policy we feel that it was in
the best interest of the students
and the University to remain
consistent with the previous
policy. At present we feel that the
freshman grading policy is
beneficial and we will work to see
that it is maintained in the future.
We would like to take this
opportunity to thank Dean
Suskind for remaining
open-minded throughout this
whole issue. His awareness of
student opinions and his concern
for student welfare were
instrumental in the adoption of
this policy.

Establishment devils luring us
into the soft life.
But people don't have a
mellow now. There are spots of
mold already on them, as they
first arrive. There is none of the
drama of salvation and
redemption, complete with evils
to conquer, for them. Their
pleasures are the passive one of
Fall Week-ends and movies on
campus, not even the daring
move of venturing into Baltimore
for such a thrill.
We are the warmed-over
remnants of a fiery past. How
can we deal with issues like
Honor Commissions — aren't all
students honorable to radicals?
And Discipline Codes — what is
discipline to a radical? And that
is why it is time to graduate, to
move on. And when we return,
maybe for the fifth year reunion,
or even the first year reunion, we
will find 3400 Festivals
somewhat tame entertainment,
and all that will really matter will
be the eerie silence of the
balloon-carrying students.

The BSR 810 and 710 have their brains in
their shaft. A carefully machined metal rod
holding eight precision-molded cams. When
the cam shaft turns, the cams make things
happen. A lock is released, an arm raises and
swings, a record drops, a platter starts spinning,
the arm is lowered, the arm stops, the arm raises
again, it swings back, another record is dropped
onto the platter, the arm is lowered again,
and so on, for as many hours as you like.
Deluxe turntables from other companies do
much the same thing, but they use many
more parts—scads of separate swinging arms,
gears, plates, and springs—in an arrangement that is not nearly as mechanically
elegant, or as quiet or reliable; that produces
considerably more vibration, and is much
more susceptible to mechanical shock than
the BSR sequential cam shaft system.
When you buy a turntable, make sure you
get the shaft. The BSR 710 and 810. From
the world's largest manufacturer of automatic
turntables.

Leake speaks on modern figurative painting
By JOE BUSCEMA
Eugene Leake, President of the
Maryland Institute, College of
Art, addressed a crowd of 50
persons in the Garrett Room of
the MSE Library, on the subject
of contemporary figurative
painting, at the Wednesday Noon
series this week.
"No good artist 'conforms' to
the history of art and he can't
avoid painting his own history,"
said Leake, an artist and a former
professor at Yale. "Most
authentic artists have a sense of
art history and where they come
from," he added.
Leake expressed his

disagreement with the view of
Harold Rosenberg who contends
the aim of every authentic artist
is not to conform to the history
of art but to replace it with his
own history. He said young
painters today want to revolt
against artists who have set
precedents in art history like
Pollack, de Kooning, or of more
recent times, Kelly, Olitski,
Rauschenberg, Morris, and
Warhol.
"Every generation, today it's
every few years, tries to
overcome the deadening
influence of the immediate'
preceding generation you've got

to throw your father out the
studio window, but then is it
possible to paint anything
worthwhile by throwing out the
history of art?" said Leake.
Leake believes there is a
refreshing movement afoot today
among many artists young and
old to return to nature, to accept
the notion expressed by art
historian Douglas Bush which
justifies the return to the study
of sixteenth and seventeenth
century European and English
classical literature and forms
because they are of sufficient
greatness to excuse dwelling on
them

"We return to that body of
literature because it is infinitely
enjoyable and the experience
may help us as individuals to
regain some elements of health
and taste that are not
conspicuous in our time," Leake
added.
"Is it so strange then that
artists are again exploring the
world of nature
- faces,
mountains, rain, trees, water, the
gesture and the incredible
expressiveness of the human
form?" he continued. "I think
maybe these artists are not
'appendages' of the past, but
harbingers of the future."
Leake proceeded to show
examples of modern figurative
paintings which have broken
away from the dominant styles
of the 20th century. Included
works of

Eugene Leake
Resika, John Salt, and Fairfield
Porter.
Some of Leake's own works
are currently on display in the
MSE Library. He will resign a, of
the summer of 1974, as President
of the Maryland Institute,
College of Art.

Hop footballers to seek third straight MAC victory
By BILL SCHOEFFLER
The Johns Hopkins football
team travels to Carlisle,
Pennsylvania tomorrow to take
on Dickinson College in the fifth
Blue Jay MAC contest of the
season. Currently holding an even
league record, Hopkins will be
seeking their third straight
conference victory. WJHU will
broadcast the game live beginning
at 2:00 p.m.
For Dickinson, the game will
wind up a disappointing 1973
season. The Red Devils own a
deceptive 1-4-2 record that
could easily be reversed given one
or two breaks a game. Among the
defeats Dickinson has suffered is
a loss to Muhlenberg by a single
point just two weeks ago.
"Dickinson is a team that can
beat anyone in the conference,"
warned Coach Dennis Cox, "but
they just haven't." Throughout
the season the Red Devils have
never been out of a ball game,
and they have even given the top
contenders a run for the money.
Twenty-four lettermen anchor

the 67 man squad playing for
Dickinson Coach Wilbur
Gobrecht. Led by captain Gene
Sienkiewicz, the Red Devils will
be trying to claim their first
victory over Hopkins in seven
years. Last season the Blue Jays
prevailed 55-20 here, but when
Hopkins played at Carlisle two
years ago a final minute
touchdown and a two point
conversion were needed to
sustain the streak.
Sienkiewicz heads the 5-3
Dickinson defense at his line
backing position. Backing up the
front wall and providing pass
defense is the job for senior
safety Gary William and his
supporting underclassmen.
Coach Cox considers
tomorrow's opponents to be
better offensively than
defensively, with an attack much
like the Blue Jays own. Senior
Jeff Truskey is an excellent
quarterback from the Jack
Thomas mold. Starting for the
third year, Truskey runs the
option effectively and throws

Harriers preparing
for Invitational meet
By JOHN TETZLAFF
With the grueling cross country
season drawing to a close, the
Blue Jays spent the week
preparing for the Galludet
Invitational Meet, which will be
run tomorrow in Washington,
D.C. The invitational should be a
good prep for next week's finale,
The Mason-Dixon Conference
Championships.
In both meets the Blue Jays
will face nearly the same
opposition and should fare well.
Hopkins has already beaten
several of the competitors this
year during the dual meet
schedule. However, they will face
a stiff challenge from meet
favorites; Catholic University and
Mount St. Mary's.
The 7-6 • season dual meet
record and the 8th place finish in
the MAC, Hopkins' best in recent
years, indicate good things to
come for the Blue Jays. This
year's squad is composed
exclusively of juniors and
freshmen, with the exception of
senior Captain Austin Doyle, and
all should be expected to return
for next season.
The MAC race itself shows the
team's progress, avenging
mid-season losses to Franklin &
Marshall and Lebanon Valley.
With the added experience, next
year's squad should be prepared
to challenge for those top
positions in the conference.
Also encouraging is the time
improvement between the early
season meet at Belmont Plateau
and the MAC championship on
the same course. Schickler,
Tetzlaff, Sailer and Kennedy all
shaved significant amounts off
their early season times.
This pattern was apparent in
the home meets, with most of
the team having their best times
on the course in the final home
meet. Perhaps this puts to rest a
recent harrier tradition of fading
with the Fall, and indicates
bright prospects for another
season. Further proof should be

had in the two remaining meets,
where good results should be
expected.
The Blue Jay offense
continued to hold the ball on
their side of the field, but at the
same time was hindered by the
inability to score.
Tomorrow the Jays will travel
to Pennsylvania to compete in
the last game of their season
against Widener (formerly PMC).
The Jays record now stands at
5-5-2. It is obvious what this
game will mean.

against Ursinus.
Truskey directed two time
consuming sustained drives last
week that were based exclusively
on the Red Devil ground game.
Junior halfback Jerry Urich
presents an outside threat to the

The blossoming of freshmen Sam

threats presented by seniors
Thomas, Billy Nolan and Harry

Booters tie in last home game
By CHUCK SLONIM
The Johns Hopkins University
soccer team could not buy a goal
last Tuesday afternoon when the
Western Maryland Green Terrors
'travelled to Homewood to
compete against the Blue Jay
booters. The score ended in a
shutout deadlock with both
teams returning to their locker
rooms scoreless after ninety
minutes of play. A new NCAA
rule allows a soccer game to end
in a knotted score as opposed to
last year's two five-minute
overtime periods.
The Blue Jays played excellent
soccer throughout the game.
Their passing was the best it has
been all season. Their shooting
game had something missing,
however. Although the Jays
outshot their opponents 26-19,
the ball just could not find its
way into the 8' x 24' goal. On
one drive, two consecutive hard
shots hit the pipe and bounded

out of bounds. Senior Bert
Arguer° had a number of
attempted head shots but just
couldn't find the opening to put
the ball in. One of his shots just
missed the top of the goal.
Offensively and defensively
the Jays had it together,
particularly in the defense. Most
Terror drives were accomplished
because of Blue Jay mistakes, but
the defensive work of
sophomores Lou Podrazik and
Joe Rutkowski along with the
fancy footwork of the only
junior on the team, Charley
"Chasbo" Gilman, did not fall
apart on any occasion.
Hopkins nettender Keith
Naunheim kept the Terrors
scoreless but on one occasion
Chasbo Gilman dropped into the
net to play goalie as Naunheim
was needed away from his
positipn in order to block an
attempted shot. With Naunheim
out and the ball rolling into the

Coach Bob Oliver
unguarded net, Chasbo swiftly
pulled into Naunheim's spot and
"single-footedly" deflected the
would.be goal.

Swimmers look strong again
By DAN MYERS
In six years at the helm of the
Johns Hopkins swimming team,
Coach Frank Comfort has built
the Blue Jays into a major
national power in the College
Division ranks. This progress is
bound to continue in 1974 as the
freshman class roster is large and
talented while only one
nationally ranked swimmer was
lost through graduation. There is
no doubt that Hopkins will have

Coach Comfort times a swimmer's practice

hiEws-lErrot

sports

some of the depth which was
lacking last year.
In addition to superstars Mark
Horning and Bill Milne and the
rest of the returning veterans,
there are fourteen freshmen,
many of whom could make a
substantial contribution to the
team this year. Comfort said of
the team, "It's the best and
largest class we've ever had. We
have to run two practice sessions
to accomodate everyone."
Leading the crew of well
trained newcomers is John
Patzschke from Loyola High
School in Towson. He is widely
regards as one of the nation's
best prep school swimmers of last
year. His talent is unique in that
he ranked as an All-American in
both long distance and sprint
freestyle events.

The increased depth of the
team has enabled the scheduling
of nationally reputed swimming
opponents including Harvard,
Ohio University, Tennessee, and
North Carolina State. These
teams added to the University of
Maryland, Navy and the Penn
Relays provide a challenge to the
Hopkins mermen. Comfort told
this reporter, "We have a strong
balanced schedule for the first
time and it's because of our
growth."
Hopkins now has a
self-perpetuating reputation in
swimming with a hard working
and dedicated team. Many of the
swimmers practiced with
Comfort or independently during
the summer. Some of the Blue
Jays even attend extra workouts
in the mornings.

All ten starters returning to Blue Jay wrestling squad
By CAT STEVENS
The Johns Hopkins Witstling team,
coached by Harry Gotwals,
promises to be a bright spot on
the campus during the dreary
winter months. The Blue Jays
have all ten of their starters
coming back. While this alone
would make any coach happy,
Gotwals also has some very tough
freshmen and upper-classmen to
add depth to the team.
"With all of last year's men
showing up and barring any
crippling injuries, we should do
as well as, if not better than last
year's 8-4 record," predicted
Coach Gotwals.
The pending competition,
however, is better than last
year's. Two teams that Hopkins
beat soundly, UMBC and
Widener, have new coaches and
should prove to be tough
opponents. Also, the addition of
George Washington University
Nimeloomemonimmr

and Messiah C.ollege gives new
and challenging blood to the
present schedule.
Currently there are about
fourteen men practicing for the
season. Coach Gotwals, who
wrestled here as an
undergraduate, would like more
people to come out, undergrads
and grads alike. "At Hopkins
wrestling and other team sports
are one of the few areas whereone
can let his frustrations out and
also meet new people," he
remarked.
The coach is eagerly waiting
for the advent of some football
players. Included in this group is
sophomore Wayne Panullo who
started at 177 lbs. last year.
Also freshman Brian Coulter,
Sam Matz and Jim Udell will
move indoors. Coulter is a tough
grappler from Wilmington
Delaware. Matz placed fourth in
Baltimore County and is

undefeated in dual meets. Udell
placed 7th in the New Mexico
AAAA State Tournament.
Other freshman vying for
starting berths are Peter Bascom,
Steve Lazzaro, Robert Nadeau,
Robert Rosenwasser and Craig
Snyder. Bascom, at 150, placed
3rd in the Maryland tournament
while Lazzaro took 1st place in
the 105 bracket. Up north
Rosenwasser took 3rd in Orange
County, NY tournament. While
those three were doing well at
home, Nadeau and Snyder were
mopping up outside the U.S.
Nadeau took 1st in the Europe
tourney for U.S. Dependent
Schools and Snyder placed 2nd
in the Far East tournament.
Meanwhile upperclassmen Mel
Morse, who sat our last year, Bill
Birmingham and Greg Goldman
are looking to break into the
line-up.

Mandel considering new aid

Money is big factor
for MSE Symposium

the next six weeks. Woodworth
noted that the entire budget
must be printed by January 1 for
the Governor's annual State of
the State address to the
Assembly.
One source in Annapolis,
however, doubted that the
Governor's first and major
budget proposal would include
the new plan for greater state
funding of private colleges and
universities. "It will probably
become part of a supplemental
budget later on in the session."
"To be frank," the source
continued, "the new plan won't
even be adoped if it means a tax
increase. Remember, this is an
election year."
The MCHE proposal emanates
from a five month study by a
special committee to develop a
permanent program of state
assistance to private higher
education.
Known as the "Pear
Committee," for its Chairman

Philip Pear who is a MCHE
member, the group presented
Mandel with an extensive 200
page report which included a
federally funded financial survey
of each of the 16 private
institutions by the New York
financial analysis firm Touche,
Ross and Company.
The Touche, Ross surveys
indicated that only five of the
sixteen institutions studied
would be operating without a
deficit in the fiscal year 1977.
Hopkins was not among the five.
The Pear Committee's report
to the Governor made three basic
recommendations:
1) That the current
distribution formula (of $500 per
degree conferred each year) be
changed to $243 per student
enrolled each year; the state
currently supports public colleges
and universities by such a
method, and the $243 figure is

noted that Therrien was in charge

and that Jorgensen had

Infirmary.

The basic function of the

complaints from students about
the Health Center.

The newly-established Issues

Hopkins Metro Center back at full operating capacity
By ALAN HIRSCH
The Hopkins Center for
Metropolitan Planning and
Research is "now working at its
normal operational level,"
according to the Center's
director, Dr. Jack Fisher.
The center has substantially
increased its staff size over the
past year, and no significant
increases in the Center's staff size
over the next few years are
foreseen by Fisher. The Center
this year employs 26 stipended
research assistants for its
projects, as compared to just two
last year.
The Metro Center, a
non-academic department of the
University which has as its
precursor the Center for Urban
Affairs, began operations last
year.

With the extensive aid of the
research assistants and three
research consultants, 19 members
of University academic
departments, and Metro Center
staffers, examine various aspects
of Urban problems through
research.
Researchers affiliated with the
Center are currently involved in
20 research programs in four
basic areas, Metropolitan
Growth, Government Service,
Social Relations in the City, and
the Environment. Research
projects involving international
exchange of men and ideas is also
a part of the Center's research
capacity.
The Center recently arranged
the visit to the U.S. of a group of
European Urban and
Environmental specialists who

SC group to meet
with Trustees Mon.
By MARK DALZELL
A six member delegation of •
the Student Council will meet
with several members of the
University's Board of Trustees
next Monday.
The upcoming meeting with
the Trustees was the primary
item for discussion on the
Student Council's Tuesday
evening agenda. The Council
also acted to approve the
selection of Amy Levin, a Junior,
as the Chairman for 3400 on
Stage and to accept the students
nominated to the Student UnIon
Governing Board, the Health
Committee, and the Issues
Committee.
Held at the request of the
Trustees and announced several
weeks ago, the meeting will cover
a broad range of topics with
emphasis on the conditions and
trends in undergraduate
education at the University.
The original members of the
Student Council chosen to meet
the Trustees were Shep
Senior Class
Hoffman
President, Dan Raab, Junior Class
President, Eric Rosenson,
Sophomore Class representative,
and Benetta Mansfield, Senior
Class representative. Since
Tuesday's SC meeting, Mark
Spatola, Freshman Class
President, and Andy Savitz,
President of the Student Council,
have been added.
President Muller and Robert
D.H. Harvey, Chairman of the
Board of Trustees, will attend the
Monday meeting. Tentatively
scheduled to appear are the
following trustees: Harrison L.
Winter, Vice-Chairman of the
Board, Morton K. Blaustein,
Alonzo G. Decker, Jr., and
Russell S. Passarella.
Yesterday, members of the
Student Council delegation met
to brief Muller on the form of
presentation to be used and the
questions to be raised by the
Council. The meeting with Muller
lasted approximately 45 minutes
and ended with Savitz being
asked, by Muller, to attend the
meeting with the Trustees.
At its Tuesday meeting the
Student Council was in
agreement with the general range
of topics to be discussed, but was

divided over the approach to be
taken with the Trustees.
Leon Barish , Junior
representative, saw the meeting
as an opportunity to expound
student philosophies on
education, while others, among
them John Colmers,
Vice-President of the SC, and
Hoffmann, stressed the need to
be more concrete and specific.
It was finally decided to
conduct the meeting as an
orientation of the Trustees in
academic conditions as viewed by
the Student Council.

Commendation
The action by the Committee on Undergraduate Studies to
reverse its earlier decision to break promised confidentiality on
first semester freshman grades is commendable, as is the
unanimous vote by the Academic Council to support the CUS
reversal. Dean Suskind is apparently willing to abide by the twin
votes, and we commend him too.
But if students can take any comfort in the fact that their
voices were heard and respected, we should take little comfort
in the fact that the policy making process precludes significant
student participation except in the form of belated reaction. We
don't believe the University would be content with educating a
bunch of reactionaries, nor do we believe students have enough
of a role in deliberating over academic policies which directly
affect their academic careers.
The events of the past two weeks (insofar as the frosh grade
confidentiality incident is concerned) point to a severely closed
academic policy-making process. If students are content with
the process as it stands, so be it.. But we suggest that students
mobilize an effort to place a representative on the Academic
Council to prevent such an incident from ever occuring again.

To the Editor:
As you know there has been
much discussion and confusion
concerning the status of first
semester grades for the classes of
'75, '76, and '77. We would like to
take this opportunity to inform
you of the status of these grades.
On Tuesday, November 6th, the
Committee on Undergraduate
Studies (CUS) voted that no first
semester freshman grades will be
released except in the following
situations:
1) Students applying for transfer
during or at the end of the
freshman year.
2) Students applying to the
Johns Hopkins University AB-MD
(2-5 Medical program.
These first semester freshman
grades will only be released at the
written request of the institution
to which the student is applying
and then only upon written
consent of the student. The grades
from the first semester shall remain
on file for the internal use of the
division of Arts and Sciences.
There will be no other exceptions
to this rule. On Wednesday,
November 7th this motion was
passed unanimously by the
Academic Council and is now in
effect.
While we recognize that some
students may be adversely affected
by this policy we feel that it was in
the best interest of the students
and the University to remain
consistent with the previous
policy. At present we feel that the
freshman grading policy is
beneficial and we will work to see
that it is maintained in the future.
We would like to take this
opportunity to thank Dean
Suskind for remaining
open-minded throughout this
whole issue. His awareness of
student opinions and his concern
for student welfare were
instrumental in the adoption of
this policy.

Letter to the Editor:
The Arabs use of oil cutbacks
to influence our foreign policy is
audacious, despicable, and
perfidious. Unfortunately, it is
also effective. Before long we
may have to walk a mile for our
Camels. But I want to warn the
Arabs that they can bet their
bottom dinar that America will
not take this kind of treatment
lying down. We are not
powerless. We manufacture
products that they need, too. So
if they continue their cutbacks,
then no more Coca-Cola and no
more Hershey bars. If that
doesn't work we'll take back our
Jerry Lewis movies. They can't
push us around and get away
with it.

can we deal with issues like
Honor Commissions — aren't all
students honorable to radicals?

discipline to a radical? And that
is why it is time to graduate, to
move on. And when we return,
maybe for the fifth year reunion,
or even the first year reunion, we
will find 3400 Festivals
somewhat tame entertainment,
and all that will really matter will
be the eerie silence of the
balloon-carrying students.

The BSR 810 and 710 have their brains in
their shaft. A carefully machined metal rod
holding eight precision-molded cams. When
the cam shaft turns, the cams make things
happen. A lock is released, an arm raises and
swings, a record drops, a platter starts spinning,
the arm is lowered, the arm stops, the arm raises
again, it swings back, another record is dropped
onto the platter, the arm is lowered again,
and so on, for as many hours as you like.
Deluxe turntables from other companies do
much the same thing, but they use many
more parts—scads of separate swinging arms,
gears, plates, and springs—in an arrangement that is not nearly as mechanically
elegant, or as quiet or reliable; that produces
considerably more vibration, and is much
more susceptible to mechanical shock than
the BSR sequential cam shaft system.
When you buy a turntable, make sure you
get the shaft. The BSR 710 and 810. From
the world's largest manufacturer of automatic
turntables.

Leake speaks on modern figurative painting
By JOE BUSCEMA
Eugene Leake, President of the
Maryland Institute, College of
Art, addressed a crowd of 50
persons in the Garrett Room of
the MSE Library, on the subject
of contemporary figurative
painting, at the Wednesday Noon
series this week.
"No good artist 'conforms' to
the history of art and he can't
avoid painting his own history,"
said Leake, an artist and a former
professor at Yale. "Most
authentic artists have a sense of
art history and where they come
from," he added.
Leake expressed his

disagreement with the view of
Harold Rosenberg who contends
the aim of every authentic artist
is not to conform to the history
of art but to replace it with his
own history. He said young
painters today want to revolt
against artists who have set
precedents in art history like
Pollack, de Kooning, or of more
recent times, Kelly, Olitski,
Rauschenberg, Morris, and
Warhol.
"Every generation, today it's
every few years, tries to
overcome the deadening
influence of the immediate'
preceding generation you've got

to throw your father out the
studio window, but then is it
possible to paint anything
worthwhile by throwing out the
history of art?" said Leake.
Leake believes there is a
refreshing movement afoot today
among many artists young and
old to return to nature, to accept
the notion expressed by art
historian Douglas Bush which
justifies the return to the study
of sixteenth and seventeenth
century European and English
classical literature and forms
because they are of sufficient
greatness to excuse dwelling on
them

"We return to that body of
literature because it is infinitely
enjoyable and the experience
may help us as individuals to
regain some elements of health
and taste that are not
conspicuous in our time," Leake
added.
"Is it so strange then that
artists are again exploring the
world of nature
- faces,
mountains, rain, trees, water, the
gesture and the incredible
expressiveness of the human
form?" he continued. "I think
maybe these artists are not
'appendages' of the past, but
harbingers of the future."
Leake proceeded to show
examples of modern figurative
paintings which have broken
away from the dominant styles
of the 20th century. Included
works of

Eugene Leake
Resika, John Salt, and Fairfield
Porter.
Some of Leake's own works
are currently on display in the
MSE Library. He will resign a, of
the summer of 1974, as President
of the Maryland Institute,
College of Art.

Hop footballers to seek third straight MAC victory
By BILL SCHOEFFLER
The Johns Hopkins football
team travels to Carlisle,
Pennsylvania tomorrow to take
on Dickinson College in the fifth
Blue Jay MAC contest of the
season. Currently holding an even
league record, Hopkins will be
seeking their third straight
conference victory. WJHU will
broadcast the game live beginning
at 2:00 p.m.
For Dickinson, the game will
wind up a disappointing 1973
season. The Red Devils own a
deceptive 1-4-2 record that
could easily be reversed given one
or two breaks a game. Among the
defeats Dickinson has suffered is
a loss to Muhlenberg by a single
point just two weeks ago.
"Dickinson is a team that can
beat anyone in the conference,"
warned Coach Dennis Cox, "but
they just haven't." Throughout
the season the Red Devils have
never been out of a ball game,
and they have even given the top
contenders a run for the money.
Twenty-four lettermen anchor

the 67 man squad playing for
Dickinson Coach Wilbur
Gobrecht. Led by captain Gene
Sienkiewicz, the Red Devils will
be trying to claim their first
victory over Hopkins in seven
years. Last season the Blue Jays
prevailed 55-20 here, but when
Hopkins played at Carlisle two
years ago a final minute
touchdown and a two point
conversion were needed to
sustain the streak.
Sienkiewicz heads the 5-3
Dickinson defense at his line
backing position. Backing up the
front wall and providing pass
defense is the job for senior
safety Gary William and his
supporting underclassmen.
Coach Cox considers
tomorrow's opponents to be
better offensively than
defensively, with an attack much
like the Blue Jays own. Senior
Jeff Truskey is an excellent
quarterback from the Jack
Thomas mold. Starting for the
third year, Truskey runs the
option effectively and throws

Harriers preparing
for Invitational meet
By JOHN TETZLAFF
With the grueling cross country
season drawing to a close, the
Blue Jays spent the week
preparing for the Galludet
Invitational Meet, which will be
run tomorrow in Washington,
D.C. The invitational should be a
good prep for next week's finale,
The Mason-Dixon Conference
Championships.
In both meets the Blue Jays
will face nearly the same
opposition and should fare well.
Hopkins has already beaten
several of the competitors this
year during the dual meet
schedule. However, they will face
a stiff challenge from meet
favorites; Catholic University and
Mount St. Mary's.
The 7-6 • season dual meet
record and the 8th place finish in
the MAC, Hopkins' best in recent
years, indicate good things to
come for the Blue Jays. This
year's squad is composed
exclusively of juniors and
freshmen, with the exception of
senior Captain Austin Doyle, and
all should be expected to return
for next season.
The MAC race itself shows the
team's progress, avenging
mid-season losses to Franklin &
Marshall and Lebanon Valley.
With the added experience, next
year's squad should be prepared
to challenge for those top
positions in the conference.
Also encouraging is the time
improvement between the early
season meet at Belmont Plateau
and the MAC championship on
the same course. Schickler,
Tetzlaff, Sailer and Kennedy all
shaved significant amounts off
their early season times.
This pattern was apparent in
the home meets, with most of
the team having their best times
on the course in the final home
meet. Perhaps this puts to rest a
recent harrier tradition of fading
with the Fall, and indicates
bright prospects for another
season. Further proof should be

had in the two remaining meets,
where good results should be
expected.
The Blue Jay offense
continued to hold the ball on
their side of the field, but at the
same time was hindered by the
inability to score.
Tomorrow the Jays will travel
to Pennsylvania to compete in
the last game of their season
against Widener (formerly PMC).
The Jays record now stands at
5-5-2. It is obvious what this
game will mean.

picked up 80 yards last week
against Ursinus.
Truskey directed two time
consuming sustained drives last
week that were based exclusively
on the Red Devil ground game.
Junior halfback Jerry Urich
presents an outside threat to the

The offense will have to play

however, for Hopkins to
capitalize on Dickinson errors.
The blossoming of freshmen Sam
Matz and Scott Smith add to the
threats presented by seniors
Thomas, Billy Nolan and Harry
Stringer. With an inspired effort
from the whole unit, a Blue Jay
win ought to be within reach.

Booters tie in last home game
By CHUCK SLONIM
The Johns Hopkins University
soccer team could not buy a goal
last Tuesday afternoon when the
Western Maryland Green Terrors
'travelled to Homewood to
compete against the Blue Jay
booters. The score ended in a
shutout deadlock with both
teams returning to their locker
rooms scoreless after ninety
minutes of play. A new NCAA
rule allows a soccer game to end
in a knotted score as opposed to
last year's two five-minute
overtime periods.
The Blue Jays played excellent
soccer throughout the game.
Their passing was the best it has
been all season. Their shooting
game had something missing,
however. Although the Jays
outshot their opponents 26-19,
the ball just could not find its
way into the 8' x 24' goal. On
one drive, two consecutive hard
shots hit the pipe and bounded

out of bounds. Senior Bert
Arguer° had a number of
attempted head shots but just
couldn't find the opening to put
the ball in. One of his shots just
missed the top of the goal.
Offensively and defensively
the Jays had it together,
particularly in the defense. Most
Terror drives were accomplished
because of Blue Jay mistakes, but
the defensive work of
sophomores Lou Podrazik and
Joe Rutkowski along with the
fancy footwork of the only
junior on the team, Charley
"Chasbo" Gilman, did not fall
apart on any occasion.

Bimini repeats as BIA flag football champs
The Bimini Bay Bombers
successfully defended their BIA
flag football crown Tuesday
afternoon in a convincing 18-6
conquest of TEP on the Wyman
Park field.
The senior independents took
command early, scoring both
times they had the ball in the
first half while stifling the
fraternity squad with an
overwhelming defensive rush.
Tom Skinner and Scott Reichard,
the only junior Bomber,
spearheaded the Bimini pressure
that kept TEP handcuffed most

of the game, thwarting efforts to
depose the champs.
Bob Barbera led the Bombers
offensively, setting up the first
touchdown and scoring the other
two himself. On the first Bimini
play from scrimmage, Barbera
skirted left end for a long gainer
up the sideline. The independents
tallied on the next snap, when
Dennis Gagamiros took a Tom
Williamson lateral and hit
Skinner in the endzone.
After pushing TEP back again,
Bimini logged another six points
when quarterback Williamson

found Barbera open in paydirt.
The score followed John
Morrison's reception good for a
first down at the ten.
The fraternity gridders
managed their lone touchdown
of the game in the last moments
of the half. Tom Nathan pulled
in a Steve Brown bomb near the
goal line. Four plays later Brown
hit Roy Nowick for TEP's score.
In the second half TEP's
defense tightened and the
Bombers were unable to move
the ball as effectively. However,
Barbera added the clincher when

Swimmers look strong again
By DAN MYERS
In six years at the helm of the
Johns Hopkins swimming team,
Coach Frank Comfort has built
the Blue Jays into a major
national power in the College
Division ranks. This progress is
bound to continue in 1974 as the
freshman class roster is large and
talented while only one
nationally ranked swimmer was
lost through graduation. There is
no doubt that Hopkins will have

Coach Comfort times a swimmer's practice

hiEws-lErrot

sports

some of the depth which was
lacking last year.
In addition to superstars Mark
Horning and Bill Milne and the
rest of the returning veterans,
there are fourteen freshmen,
many of whom could make a
substantial contribution to the
team this year. Comfort said of
the team, "It's the best and
largest class we've ever had. We
have to run two practice sessions
to accomodate everyone."
Leading the crew of well
trained newcomers is John
Patzschke from Loyola High
School in Towson. He is widely
regards as one of the nation's
best prep school swimmers of last
year. His talent is unique in that
he ranked as an All-American in
both long distance and sprint
freestyle events.

The increased depth of the
team has enabled the scheduling
of nationally reputed swimming
opponents including Harvard,
Ohio University, Tennessee, and
North Carolina State. These
teams added to the University of
Maryland, Navy and the Penn
Relays provide a challenge to the
Hopkins mermen. Comfort told
this reporter, "We have a strong
balanced schedule for the first
time and it's because of our
growth."
Hopkins now has a
self-perpetuating reputation in
swimming with a hard working
and dedicated team. Many of the
swimmers practiced with
Comfort or independently during
the summer. Some of the Blue
Jays even attend extra workouts
in the mornings.

All ten starters returning to Blue Jay wrestling squad
By CAT STEVENS
The Johns Hopkins Witstling team,
coached by Harry Gotwals,
promises to be a bright spot on
the campus during the dreary
winter months. The Blue Jays
have all ten of their starters
coming back. While this alone
would make any coach happy,
Gotwals also has some very tough
freshmen and upper-classmen to
add depth to the team.
"With all of last year's men
showing up and barring any
crippling injuries, we should do
as well as, if not better than last
year's 8-4 record," predicted
Coach Gotwals.
The pending competition,
however, is better than last
year's. Two teams that Hopkins
beat soundly, UMBC and
Widener, have new coaches and
should prove to be tough
opponents. Also, the addition of
George Washington University
Nimeloomemonimmr

and Messiah C.ollege gives new
and challenging blood to the
present schedule.
Currently there are about
fourteen men practicing for the
season. Coach Gotwals, who
wrestled here as an
undergraduate, would like more
people to come out, undergrads
and grads alike. "At Hopkins
wrestling and other team sports
are one of the few areas whereone
can let his frustrations out and
also meet new people," he
remarked.
The coach is eagerly waiting
for the advent of some football
players. Included in this group is
sophomore Wayne Panullo who
started at 177 lbs. last year.
Also freshman Brian Coulter,
Sam Matz and Jim Udell will
move indoors. Coulter is a tough
grappler from Wilmington
Delaware. Matz placed fourth in
Baltimore County and is

undefeated in dual meets. Udell
placed 7th in the New Mexico
AAAA State Tournament.
Other freshman vying for
starting berths are Peter Bascom,
Steve Lazzaro, Robert Nadeau,
Robert Rosenwasser and Craig
Snyder. Bascom, at 150, placed
3rd in the Maryland tournament
while Lazzaro took 1st place in
the 105 bracket. Up north
Rosenwasser took 3rd in Orange
County, NY tournament. While
those three were doing well at
home, Nadeau and Snyder were
mopping up outside the U.S.
Nadeau took 1st in the Europe
tourney for U.S. Dependent
Schools and Snyder placed 2nd
in the Far East tournament.
Meanwhile upperclassmen Mel
Morse, who sat our last year, Bill
Birmingham and Greg Goldman
are looking to break into the
line-up.
Returning senior co-captains

CHARLIE
CHAPLIN
in

Neil Hazard and Craig Stevens
will be joined by junior Clark
Kingery as team leaders this
season. Hazard, a persistent
grappler wracked up 10 wins
against 2 losses last year at 190. In
two years Hazard has gained 98
team points for the Blue Jays.
Stevens had a 9-3 record last year
at 167 and has collected 10 pins
in 24 matches during his career
here. Unfortunately he is still
recovering from knee surgery but
expects to be wrestling by
January. Kingery, also 9-3 last
year, wrestled at 134. In the
MAC Tournament the junior
took 4th place and he holds two
JHU records for reversals, 15 for
one season and 29 for a career.
Two other 4th place finishers
are Ron Pucillo at 118 and Rob
Fink at 142. Pucillo had a 7-4-1
record last year and currently
holds the JHU records for most
near falls (13) and escapes (18).

Fink, inventor of the now
famous Inky Dink move, had an
8-3 record and tied Pucillo with
13 near falls.
Gary Murza, a freshman
standout, with an 11-1
heavyweight record last year, is
hoping to drop down to 190.
This should prove to be
interesting as he and Hazard
battle it out for the spot. Murza
garnered 56 team points last
year, a new record. Other
freshmen starters returning from
last year are Dave Mulock at 158
and Mike Privitera at 126.
Mulock with a 7-5 record and
Privitera at 5-6-1 are both tough
competitors and should do much
better this year.
With the help of the Hopkins
trainer, Leroy "Brandy"
Brandimore, in keeping his
grapplers healthy, Coach Gotwals
should have a very good season
and finish better than last year
